comments.commentBody: Very confused at the start, and I struggled. I use Across Lite and didn't realize there was anything in the Notepad for a while, and then when I read it I was even further confused. So many levels, which all makes sense once you get it but are hardly helpful when you're trying to wrap your head around what to do. Reminds me of some of kid's video games. Thrash around until you happen upon the right solution. Few "witty" or "clever" clues, making it especially arduous and not very satisfying.
I do hope we get it through... and use it as a springboard to achieve the more trenchant reforms that we desperately need.

even the Democrats can't find the votes for this failed legislation with false numbers, and false hope. We keep hearing these sob stories from the White House, but the people involved will not be helped for 4 years - after death in some cases!

This Fiasco must be stopped now!

This is fascinating, as so many people can't sleep well.  I imagine that the economy is causing many people to worry instead of sleeping now. ( More doctors need to take their own advice on healthy habits! ) Sleep is when the cells repair and the psyche repairs in the form of dreams.  The immune system is enhanced by proper sleep.  This will be the next trend like eating locally grown food or taking vitamin D pills!
Nice job Big East, should have been 0-4.  Pac 10 might yet outlast you in our worst year ever.  Way to play big when it matters...  You should watch more games out West to see real basketball

An upset of epic dimension
Would halt Villanova's ascension;
But God's beneficial --
He let the official
Provide the divine intervention.

News Short n' Sweet by JFD8
http://twitter.com/JFD8

I went to the Pearl Theatre's excellent "Hard Times" and most of the actors were remarkable in playing multiple parts and changing accents (from Sleary to Grandgrind) as they changed their hats. But one actor's accent, regardless of the character and sometimes mid-speech, floated all around England: from London to the Midlands to Yorkshire, before settling somewhere in the West Indies and staying there. But even this actor was still compelling, I have to say.

Hello, All.

Yesterday was a so-called "rebus" crossword puzzle. Unfortunately, the puzzle itself seemed to generate a bit of ill-will, so I've held off my post until today.

I love Rebus puzzles; by that I mean "real" Rebus puzzles. They are often very inventive and can take all sorts of sizes and shapes. Here's a link to some examples:

http://www.fun-with-words.com...

As you can see, these rebuses have color and letter and word placement set in a way so as to describe a phrase. When I was younger, they would also be pictures with +'s and -'s that, again, would lead to a (sounded out) phrase. The "fun" is the difference between what you see (at first) and what you say!

My problem is that cramming multiple letters into a single box seems like an obscure form of "rebus" (if it's even a rebus at all). For instance, in general, no phrase is created.

I'm wondering if someone could give me some of the background as to how "rebus" has come to be associated with multiple-letters-in-one-box crossword puzzles.

Thanks,

-- jpgaskell

Sorry, somehow posted this under restaurants.

If you're there with kids:

1) The bowling at Diamond Superbowl is a lot of fun.
2) The waterpark at Dam Sen is great, though it can get pretty busy.
3) The Ben Thanh Market offers a lot to see and buy without ever feeling overwhelming.

It's a great city but never as engaging and inspiring as Hanoi.

David Hogg
My Little Nomads
(The Family Travel site)

Ouch!

Proper names at 20A, 21D (I was thinking fashion) & 34A left me with 2 holes.

It's my understanding that lacrosse was the national sport of Canada for a long time, but now (since 1994 per Wikipedia) it's the summer sport and hockey is the winter sport. I think curling is trying to sneak in there, too.

-- jpgaskell

will the elections resolve some of the issues related to Kirkuk? beyond just the Sunni-Shia-Kurdish parties, how did the other minority parties fare, such as Assyrians, Christians, Turkmen, or Yazidi's?

so far from what i've read, none of the major Iraqi political figures and parties made a big deal about US troops in the country, and the timetable. is that a correct assessment? and if so, why do you think that is the case.

thanks!

What are the odds Allawi can actually gather a coalition and become prime minister, given that his prime constituency, the Sunni Arabs, are on the opposite side of the Kirkuk issue vis a vis the Kurds?

I have 3 things to say:

1. yay! I finished a Friday! (putting Trip P. on my Christmas list)
2. I laughed at HULADANCER for "person with a shaky story" !
3. In the last week I have finally succumbed to trying KenKen puzzles and just as I feared, am now a full blown addict (sigh)....(gazing longingly at all the books I want to read...now where are those new kenkens.....)

thanks Trip and Will and Jim...very satisfying puzzle...cheers!
ps love the constructors' photos, Jim, very much appreciated!

Someday I will learn to recheck the grid for 'doesn't make sense' squares. KERSEE, not KerseY/YERO. Otherwise, this puzzle yielded to the 'chip away at it and you'll git 'er done' approach. The junk-drawer in my mind yielded HEMATITE and ALICANTE, and after that it was smooth sailing.

I did really want BUNBURY instead of ERNEST, but one can't have everything--or so I hear. (Come to think of it, I haven't had a STROH'S in about 28 years, since leaving Cincinnati. Even if I could find one, couldn't afford it--and I'm not talking about the money. Being slim all one's early life is bad training for Being Sixty-something.)

Mother-in-law is out of the slammer! I mean, hospital--weak, but way better. Thanks to the puzzles and blog for helping me through this week!

Toof, the problem isn't that a FEW races are parades; but that FEW races are close.  I'll accept a few parades if most are exciting, close races.  We haven't seen that, and usually only do when the track is either wet (rain), or there's an accident or something that shuffles the field (not what I want to see).

I'm with MRoshi. For years, the FIA has instituted rule changes to make passing easier (grooved tires? You've GOT to be kidding me) while ignoring the 800 pound gorilla blocking every driver on the course.

Ban wings and diffusers, clean up the air behind these cars and cause drivers to have to slow considerably more for turns, and passing will return.

BTW: Despite David Hobbes and other commentators consistent claims that passing isn't that important to F1 fans - that it's all about precision and technology - not just we spectators, but even those same commentators sure do get excited about actual on-track passing and pass attempts.

We just returned from our 2nd stay at Marina Phuket Resort, www.marinaphuket.com on Karon Beach. The villas sit amongst a rain forest which slopes right down to the beach, or 2 pools on the property. It's quiet and relaxing. The town has shops and restaurants without being crazy. Smaller and quieter than Kata.

Expat25
These games have really messed my bracket up. Villanova almost destroyed because I have them going to the championship game. http://sosportz.blogspot.com

As I write this post, the Penguins are beating the Bruins--at Boston on a night that Bobby Orr is in the house--2-0! The game is a total anti-climax. Cooke had a pro forma fight with Thornton on his first shift, and that's it. Whoops, now it's 3-0 Penguins! The Bruins are responding tonight the way they responded in the game that Cooke cheapshotted Savard -- with zip, zero, nothing. They will give the equally lifeless Rangers a heck of a battle for that impressive eighth playoff spot. Dreadful!

Really good post, Stu. I can't think of anyone I've read who's chronicled the head shot saga of the last couple years better.

And by the by, thanks for the Black Flag. Good taste.

king - I'll make just a few points in response to your comments, for which I thank you. First, what Wisniewski did has nothing at all to do with the post-lockout rules. I do think that some of what has occurred in the way of high speed hits does result from the absence of obstruction in that legal hits (as well as illegal hits) are more damaging than ever before. But I don't buy the notion that so much of the escalation in dangerous play is a consequence of the rules. I think it has something to do with the a greater degree of parity and having more at stake in the average game, which heightens the demands put on the players. Retaliation for perfectly clean body checks has nothing to do with the post-lockout rules.

Second, and related to the previous point, I think that there is actually more checking, more body contact today than before the lockout, which is contrary to what lots of traditionalists believe. Yes, the battles in front of the net -- which were very obvious and very entertaining -- are nothing like they used to be, but the lack of obstruction is causing much more body contact in open ice and along the boards. .

Finally, I know it is also fashionable for traditionalists to blame the media for some sort of softening of the game but the change in the rules is something the GMs debate and advocate and I can assure you that is one group that is not greatly influenced by the media and whatever opinions are expressed in it. Additionally, the players have an increasing amount of say in the way the game is played and the rules through the NHLPA and on things like the Competition Committee. It is flattering to think that those of us who have opinions on the game carry some sort of weight in these matters but I tend to think we have far, far less impact than some believe.

Thornton's getting the better of Cooke in that one instance is hardly avenging the Bruins' honor. The Bruins failure to retaliate the first time around told you all you need to know about the heart/honor of the Bruins. Hockey has changed, is changing, and will change more, but heart or guts or jam or honor or whatever you want to call it is in short supply on the Boston bench. Maybe they just don't like each other, because it's evident they have very little interest in sticking up for each other. And that, for the time being anyway, is a big part, if not the biggest part, of what hockey is all about.

king - Fair point. But here's the stats, and take them for what they're worth. Playing for the Wild, Gaborik led or tied for the team lead in GWGs five straight years, including seasons when he missed significant games due to injury. In a sixth year, he finished second. Twice, he was among the top 10 in the NHL in GWGs.

Once Jokinen developed into a consistent scorer, he led the Panthers in GWGs four straight years and finished second in the fifth.

In all these seasons, these two players were most often the leading scorer on their respective clubs

GWG's is not always a precise stat, but I think these stats does indicate that that these two played essential roles in whatever success their teams had.

What is a surprise to me are the words "Oliver Perez still in a Mets uniform".   I honestly hope Ollie overcomes his deficiencies and becomes the pitcher Omar and Jerry still trust he can become.  But, yeah, I'll take consistency for now.
